name: Baby steps
intro: Welcome to the wonderful world of combinatory logic,
a lovechild of Lisp and Brainfuck, developed in the 1930s by
Moses Sch√∂nfinkel and Haskell Curry.
A combinator is a function of one argument that takes a combinator and returns a combinator.
This alone, given a powerful enough set of starting terms, achieves Turing completeness.
That will be demonstrated in subsequent exercises, in a multitude of ways.
The tradition is to depict the combinators as birds, and we are not stepping too far away from it.
On the notation: we'll be typically using single capital letters for well-known combinators,
lowercase letters for free variables, and lowercase words for function built from other functions.
Uppercase letters can be lumped together and lowercase terms should be separated with spaces.
So XYfoo x (SII) is a shorthand for X(Y)(foo)(x)(S(I)(I)).
On the reduction: reduction always happens in the leftmost term of a (sub-)expression.
Examples to follow soon. Let's dive right in!

name: Dull tales
intro: An arbitrary lambda expression can be converted to SKI via the following rules:
<ul>
• λ x . x ⇒ I;
• λ x . f(x) (where f is independent of x) ⇒ f;
• λ x . y (where y does not depend on x) ⇒ K y;
• λ x . y(z) ⇒ S(λ x . y)(λ x . z),
where y & z may or may not depend on x.
Let's grind a bit to gain some XP before we can get to interesting stuff!

name: Swing, swing!
intro: Let's move some arguments around.
Just like in many chess and math problems, work backwards:
what λ-expression do you want to see before applying to the last argument?
Then construct it via the above technique and go one argument back,
until you run out of them.

name: The BCKW forest
intro: As you progress discovering more and more combinators,
you find out that some of them can thrive on their own.
In fact, as you wander further, you find yourself surrounded by a think forest
built entirely of four combinators:
B, C, K, and W.
Can you find the way back?
See also: BCKW system
on wikipedia.

name: The island of Iota
intro: Now you know two bases: the SK(I) and the BCKW.
Apparently, there is a one element base: X = x → xSK. Try it!

name: Boolean logic
intro: K and KI terms may be interpreted as true and false
, respectively, as K then else will result in then
and KI then else will result in else.
The trick is almost always to feed a function to a boolean value, and not the other way around.

name: Recursion
intro: Say we need to construct a combinator f that satisfies f x = foo(f, x) for a given foo.
We can't do that directly because both parts contain f.
However, assume f = g g:
g g x = foo((g g) x)
Now let's rename one of the g's:
h g x = foo((g g) x)
now h can be calculated from here, and h(h) gives f
with the required properties.
Be careful though, as immediate execution of h(h) inside h(h)
will hang the interpreter.
You might want to use x ⇒ y ⇒ x(x) combinator from one of the above quests,
or invent your own!

name: The Church of Numerals
intro: As everything in the world of combinators is a function, numbers are functions, too.
A Church numeral (named after
Alonzo Church)
is a function N that takes 2 arguments, x and y,
and returns x(...N times...(x(y))...).
By that definition, 0 is KI (just as false),
as it repeats the first argument exactly 0 times,
and 1 is I (easy to confuse).
